Award.AwardTitle: AF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Sparse Approximation: Theory and Extensions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the past ten years the theoretical computer science, applied math and electrical engineering communities have extensively studied variants of the problem of ``solving" an under-determined linear system. One common mathematical feature that allows us to solve these problems is sparsity; roughly speaking, as long as the unknown vector does not contain too many non-zero components (or has a few dominating components), we can ``solve'' the under-determined system for the unknown vector. These problems are referred to as sparse approximation problems and have applications in diverse areas such as signal and image processing, biology, imaging, tomography, machine learning and others.
The proposed research project aims to develop a comprehensive, rigorous theory of sparse approximation, broadly defined. The research proposal entails two complementary research directions:
(1) a robust and more complete view of the combinatorial, algorithmic, and complexity-theoretic foundations of sparse approximations (including its generalization to functional sparse approximation where we want to ``solve" for some function of the unknown vector instead of the vector itself),
(2) coupled with either its interactions or direct applications in other areas of theoretical computer science, from complexity theory to coding theory, and of electrical engineering, from signal processing to analog-to-digital converters.
A general theory of sparse approximation that concentrates both on the optimal tradeoffs between competing parameters and the computational feasibility of attaining such tradeoffs will not only help explore the theoretical limits and possibilities of sparse approximations, but also feed algorithmic techniques and theoretical benchmarks back to its application areas. Sparse approximation already has been shown to have impact in a variety of fields, including imaging and signal processing, Internet traffic analysis, and design of experiments in biology and drug design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematically, any data can be viewed as "signal" objects, and sparse approximation methods are ways to represent and reason about such  signals using very small ("sparse")  number of elements chosen from certain dictionaries. These representations will not be precise, but they will be approximate. In many applications, one does not need the large signals, but these small approximations will suffice. Such small approximations will exist only if suitable dictionaries are found. The goal of this project was to  (a) investigate rich new applications and suitable dictionaries, (b) invent algorithmic methods for finding and using such sparse approximations, and (c) identify connections between these problems and others well known in complexity theory, coding theory etc., so ultimately a complexity theory of sparse approximation problems is developed. 

The major developments are as follows. For data that is very high dimensions and very high cardinality, we designed a new sketch called the "graphical sketch", which very efficiently provides sparse approximation of such signals. For signals that are graphs, we developed algorithms that use much less space than was previously known to estimate the size of matchings. We develop algorithms that use the least space one can imagine -- one or two words of memory -- for analyzing signal streams, an area we call "frugal streaming". These developments identify and make progress on significant new grounds in our understanding of the complexity of sparse approximation problems. 

Further, we have pursued a number of application areas for sparse approximation problems such as finding cohorts of users in web search, identifying few topical interests of social network users, providing private ways to analyze signals in multiple ways, finding patterns in scientific publications and communities, as well as understanding high dimensional prices in online advertising systems. These developments significantly extend the sources of data where sparse approximation methods have found uses. 

The specific techniques we have introduced such as graphical sketches, sampling of graph nodes for matching estimation and discrepancy techniques for private data analysis are interesting beyond our discipline and likely to find applications in other areas such as  machine learning, data mining and operations research. Further, our methods in applied areas might help in improved web search, more effective online advertising, and more principled ways to quantify interests and impacts of social and academic users. Uses of sparse approximation methods for providing private signal analysis is of general interest to the society. 

During the project, we trained one postdoctoral researcher, 10 graduate students, and 1 undergraduate student, among them three female students. We collaborated with partners from Adobe, Microsoft and other corporations, who have applied and studied our methods on signals of interest to them. Our products including research publications are publicly available to the community. Our work has been discussed in neustar and adexchanger blogs which address larger community of practitioners in the industry.
